markdownRemark.html:
New Study Guide: Depth-First Search (DFS)

Question

Given a graph G(V,E)G(V, E)G(V,E), where VVV is the set of vertices and EEE is the set of edges, write an algorithm using Depth-First Search (DFS) to traverse the graph and output the order of traversal.

Answer in Software (JavaScript)

Here’s how you would implement DFS in JavaScript, with comments to connect the math terms to the programming logic:

// DFS Implementation in JavaScript
function dfs(graph, start, visited = new Set()) {
    // Mark the current node as visited (corresponds to S = S ∪ {v} in math)
    visited.add(start);

    // Visit the current node (corresponds to "Visit v" in math)
    console.log(start); // Output the current vertex

    // Recursively visit all neighbors of the current node
    for (let neighbor of graph[start]) {
        // Check if the neighbor has not been visited (corresponds to v' ∉ S)
        if (!visited.has(neighbor)) {
            dfs(graph, neighbor, visited); // Apply DFS to the neighbor (recursive step)
        }
    }
}

// Example graph represented as an adjacency list
const graph = {
    A: ['B', 'C'], // A connects to B and C
    B: ['A', 'D', 'E'], // B connects to A, D, and E
    C: ['A', 'F'], // C connects to A and F
    D: ['B'], // D connects to B
    E: ['B', 'F'], // E connects to B and F
    F: ['C', 'E']  // F connects to C and E
};

// Call DFS starting at vertex 'A'
console.log("DFS Traversal:");
dfs(graph, 'A');

Output

DFS Traversal:
A
B
D
E
F
C

Answer in Math

Input:

Given a graph G(V,E)G(V, E)G(V,E):

  • VVV: The set of vertices.
  • EEE: The set of edges.

Example graph:

  • V={A,B,C,D,E,F}V = \{A, B, C, D, E, F\}V={A,B,C,D,E,F}
  • E={(A,B),(A,C),(B,D),(B,E),(C,F),(E,F)}E = \{(A, B), (A, C), (B, D), (B, E), (C, F), (E, F)\}E={(A,B),(A,C),(B,D),(B,E),(C,F),(E,F)}

Algorithm (DFS Steps):

  1. Initialization:

    • Define GGG as the graph.
    • Start with an empty set SSS for visited nodes.
    • Choose an initial vertex v0v_0v0​ as the starting point.

  2. Recursion:

    • Visit v0v_0v0​ and add it to SSS: S=S∪{v0}S = S \cup \{v_0\}S=S∪{v0​}.
    • For each neighbor v′v'v′ of v0v_0v0​ (where (v0,v′)∈E(v_0, v') \in E(v0​,v′)∈E):
      • If v′∉Sv' \notin Sv′∈/S, recursively apply DFS(v′)DFS(v')DFS(v′).

  3. Termination:

    • Stop when all vertices reachable from v0v_0v0​ are visited.

Mathematical Representation:

  1. Let S=∅S = \emptysetS=∅ (visited nodes).
  2. Define the function:
    DFS(v)={Visit v,if v∉SS=S∪{v},mark v as visitedFor each v′ such that (v,v′)∈E,apply DFS(v′) if v′∉SDFS(v) = \begin{cases} \text{Visit } v, & \text{if } v \notin S \\ S = S \cup \{v\}, & \text{mark } v \text{ as visited} \\ \text{For each } v' \text{ such that } (v, v') \in E, & \text{apply } DFS(v') \text{ if } v' \notin S \end{cases}DFS(v)=⎩⎨⎧​Visit v,S=S∪{v},For each v′ such that (v,v′)∈E,​if v∈/Smark v as visitedapply DFS(v′) if v′∈/S​
  3. Output the sequence of visited vertices in order of traversal.

Example Traversal:

  1. Start at AAA: S={A}S = \{A\}S={A}.
  2. Visit BBB: S={A,B}S = \{A, B\}S={A,B}.
  3. Visit DDD: S={A,B,D}S = \{A, B, D\}S={A,B,D}.
  4. Backtrack to BBB, visit EEE: S={A,B,D,E}S = \{A, B, D, E\}S={A,B,D,E}.
  5. Visit FFF: S={A,B,D,E,F}S = \{A, B, D, E, F\}S={A,B,D,E,F}.
  6. Backtrack to CCC, visit CCC: S={A,B,D,E,F,C}S = \{A, B, D, E, F, C\}S={A,B,D,E,F,C}.

Traversal order:

A→B→D→E→F→CA \to B \to D \to E \to F \to CA→B→D→E→F→C

Connecting Math to JavaScript

  1. Graph G(V,E)G(V, E)G(V,E):

    • Represented as an adjacency list in JavaScript.
    • VVV: The keys of the object (A, B, C, etc.).
    • EEE: The arrays of connected nodes (['B', 'C'], etc.).

  2. Visited Set SSS:

    • Represented by a Set object in JavaScript (new Set()).

  3. Recursive Traversal:

    • S=S∪{v0}S = S \cup \{v_0\}S=S∪{v0​}: Translates to visited.add(start).
    • For neighbors v′v'v′: Use a loop (for (let neighbor of graph[start])).
    • Recursive DFS call: Matches DFS(v′)DFS(v')DFS(v′) if v′∉Sv' \notin Sv′∈/S.

  4. Output:

    • Print vvv: Matches console.log(start) in the code.
